image.altText: The fossilised stump of a tree amongst the rocks an sand of a beach.

props.synopsis: Weather conditions and shifting sands temporarily reveal ancient forest remains, preserved from thousands of years ago.Â

title.children: Preserved ancient 'elder trees' uncovered on Tasmanian beach after storm surge shifts sand

image.altText: A male artist with bleached blonde hair and beanie sits on couch with large green octopus toy and holds his artworks

props.synopsis: Dyscalculia, which Alfie Barker describes as being like "dyslexia but for maths", receives only a fraction of the research funding its literacy counterpart does, and experts believe that needs to change.

title.children: When you suffer from dyscalculia â€” like 'dyslexia but for maths' â€” even driving can be off limits

image.altText: Women in blue suits dance on documents with red signs

props.synopsis: The female artist behind the "women only" lounge at the centre of a discrimination complaint from a man who was refused entry says the space at Hobart's Mona will close.

title.children: Will Mona's Ladies Lounge close? Confusion as artist walks back comments, says it may 'go on tour'

image.altText: Man attends to small fire in bushland.

props.synopsis: While large burns to reduce fuel loads are the Western way, this Aboriginal-led group is training people in the traditional ways of fire management to look after the landscape.

title.children: 'Everything has a role to play': Mosaic burns taught in Aboriginal-led cultural burning workshop

image.altText: Woman stands in poultry shed holding rooster

props.synopsis: The dumping of poultry on roadsides in Tasmania is such an issue some hotspots are known as "chook" or "rooster corners". It's prompted amnesty and rehoming days where hundreds of birds are surrendered and adopted into new homes.Â

title.children: Did you miss? ðŸ“£ Unwanted poultry rehomed as roosters abandoned amid higher cost of living

image.altText: Smoke billows over a skyline

props.synopsis: The Israeli military says it launched a wave of artillery and air strikes on Hamas infrastructure in Gaza and Beirut's south to thwart what it said was an imminent attack. Follow live.

title.children: Fighting intensifies between Israel and Iran-backed militia on October 7 anniversary, with fresh strikes in Beirut and Gaza

image.altText: The Israeli flag hanging from the frame of a house.

props.synopsis: One year ago, Hamas militants infiltrated Be'eri kibbutz. It was one of many coordinated attacks across Israel that began the Israel-Hamas war â€” and a delayed response by the Israeli defence force has been blamed for some of the 101 deaths, and dozens taken hostage.Â

title.children: Hundreds dead, no answers. These Israelis want to know why the IDF failed them

image.altText: A woman walks amid rubble with her young daughter in hand, who's wearing a red dress.

props.synopsis: On October 7, 2023, Palestinians in Gaza were doing normal, everyday things, until their lives quickly turned upside down. One year later, we take a look at what happened inside Gaza through the lived experience of two Palestinians.Â

title.children: The war in Gaza has raged for a whole year. This is what it has been like for those who lived through it

image.altText: The flags of Iran and the United States of America behind a petrol pump.

props.synopsis: A day after oil prices surged, US President Joe Biden warned Israel against military strikes on Iran's oil export facilities for good reason â€” any attack could ignite another bout of inflation, and possibly plunge the world into recession.

title.children: How the Middle East could derail the global economy

image.altText: Rows of milk cartons lined up in a shop fridge

props.synopsis: There is currently no law requiring grocery stores to display visible pricing on their shelves, creating a legal loophole that leaves some shoppers "flying blind" when it comes to the weekly shop.

title.children: 'There would be outrage': Shoppers confused and frustrated by shops with no prices

image.altText: Yvonne Stretton sits with Dr Kean-Seng Lim in his office.

props.synopsis: Data from the Royal Australian College of GPs shows doctors are spending longer with patients but are worried about their financial viability as more patients either delay or avoid making appointments.

title.children: Good GPs are 'invisible' but this doctor uses maths to measure success

image.altText: Tanya Plibersek holds a python at Parliament House

props.synopsis: Shortly after starting as minister, Tanya Plibersek laid out a plan to put the environment back on the national agenda. Two years on, as Australia hosts a global summit, Michael Slezak looks at how things have gone.

title.children: She said Australians 'voted for the environment' in 2022. Two years on, what's Tanya Plibersek been able to achieve?

image.altText: Banking apps appear on a phone screen

props.synopsis: Consumer groups are calling on the government to abandon parts of new draft scam laws, saying they are unworkable and put the onus of proof on victims seeking compensation.Â

title.children: Growing backlash over new draft scam laws as consumer groups unite to condemn government victim compo proposal

image.altText: AntonioMichell-4

props.synopsis: Antonio was a specialist trauma physio in Chile. In Australia, he has swept floors and driven rideshare for years waiting for recognition, despite a physio shortage.

title.children: 'We have doctors driving rideshare': Government urged to streamline overseas qualification schemes

image.altText: Kangaroo threatened by bushfire

props.synopsis: The group warns climate change will cause more regular and severe natural disasters that will overwhelm the ability of the federal government and its agencies to help protect and rebuild communities.

title.children: 'Unimaginable new extremes': Call for 'emergency mobilisation' to deal with climate change threats

image.altText: Christos Tsiolkas crosses his arms and stands at a pool in front of signage declaring "deep water".

props.synopsis: Christos Tsiolkas is one of Australia's most celebrated authors, but as a young man he nearly left the country after experiencing 'absolute euphoria' overseas.

title.children: 'I was wrong': The piece of writing that author Christos Tsiolkas regrets to this day

image.altText: A wire fence surrounds the yard at an immigration detention centre.

props.synopsis: More asylum seekers could be released and financially compensated if a newly launched class action on behalf of South Sudanese refugees succeeds.

title.children: Fresh test for immigration system amid push to release and compensate more asylum seekers

image.altText: A young woman smiling broadly and hugging another woman.

props.synopsis: There have been tears of joy and relief as hundreds of Australians evacuated from Lebanon touched down in Sydney on the first of two government-assisted repatriation flights.

title.children: Tears of joy and relief as hundreds of Australians fleeing conflict in Lebanon touch down in Sydney

image.altText: Two men pick up award on stage

props.synopsis: The winners for medicine are selected by the Nobel Assembly of Sweden's Karolinska Institute medical university and receive a prize sum of $1.6 million.

title.children: US duo Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun win Nobel Prize in Medicine

image.altText: a graphic with politicans and a deep fake photo surrounding my social media icons

props.synopsis: As technology advances, there are concerns digitally manipulated content could shape the outcome of elections and become a threat to how people perceive democracy.

title.children: Australia's first political deepfake labelled Queensland 'cooked'. Since then, they've only become harder to detect

image.altText: A blurry image of a boat sinking

props.synopsis: A Samoan man said oil from the sunk HMNZS Manawanui was identifiable along the coast for several kilometres which would have a "massive impact".

title.children: Fears of 'crazy' environmental impact after NZ naval ship sinks off Samoa's south

image.altText: The aircraft carrier USS Theodore Roosevelt departs Naval Base Guam

props.synopsis: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba wants an end to his country's "asymmetrical" security relationship with the United States.

title.children: Japan's new prime minister proposes base in Guam, where locals celebrate liberation from Japan

image.altText: A glass office building exterior reflects other buildings.

props.synopsis: "They got away with it" is a common refrain after corporate scandals that end without consequences for individuals. A landmark High Court ruling could radically reshape that.

title.children: High Court ruling might mean corporate executives face 'lower bar' for prosecutions

image.altText: Picture of dam wall in Toowoomba region.

props.synopsis: Dozens of dams need to be upgraded across Queensland at a cost of more than $3 billion, prompting calls for the next state government to offer financial support.

title.children: Mandatory dam upgrades costing councils millions but 'not adding one extra millimetre' of storage

image.altText: gopro footage of a person walking over a deep pit

props.synopsis:
An experimental study asked 21 people to watch short videos relating to three situations. Here's what the researchers found.


Â

title.children: Spiders, heights, and social situations â€” not all fears are created equal, study suggests

image.altText: Partly smiling older woman with shaggy brown hair cut short, wears black and white striped tee and a necklace around her neck

props.synopsis: With its picturesque canals and waterfront homes, the Victorian holiday haven of Paynesville appears immune to the poverty that is quietly gripping the nation. But Foodbank Victoria says the reality is much harsher than it looks.

title.children: Hunger relief charity struggles as food insecurity becomes a 'disaster behind closed doors'

image.altText: Giant screen on the wall of the ASX, with large red numbers, showing the price of shares which have fallen.

props.synopsis: US stocks tumble into the red, while oil prices rise on Middle East conflict fears. Local stocks are tipped to dip at the open. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.Â

title.children: Wall Street loses 1 per cent, ASX to dip

image.altText: A close up image of a man with blond hair in a suit.

props.synopsis: The Apprentice tells the story of Donald Trump and late mentor Roy Cohn as the former US president climbed to the top of the real estate ladder in 1980s New York City.

title.children: Donald Trump didn't want this film released before the US election â€” and it's been a lightning rod for controversy

image.altText: The fossilised stump of a tree amongst the rocks an sand of a beach.

props.synopsis: Weather conditions and shifting sands temporarily reveal ancient forest remains, preserved from thousands of years ago.Â

title.children: Preserved ancient 'elder trees' uncovered on Tasmanian beach after storm surge shifts sand

image.altText: A headshot of a man in a suit.

props.synopsis: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade says it "makes no apology" for Australia's views on Iran's strikes on Israel, after Iranian state reported the Australian ambassador had been summoned by Tehran.

title.children: 'Australia makes no apology': Government hits back after Australian ambassador summoned by Iran

image.altText: A large crowd holding signs and waving jewsih flags work through a Melbourne street.

props.synopsis: In cities across the country, candles are being lit to mark one year since the Hamas terror attack on October 7, and the subsequent months of war in Gaza.Â

title.children: One year on from the October 7 attack, communities across Australia are pausing to remember those who have been lost

image.altText: two men look down as the look through the wreckage of a city building

props.synopsis: In Beirut at night, you hear the constant low-level hum of Israeli drones. Sometimes, when it appears two or three drones hover over a target, the sound reaches a crescendo and a massive explosion often follows. Hezbollah is unable to shoot down any of these drones which present a round-the-clock threat.

title.children: The newest war in the Middle East is an asymmetric one â€” and Israel is winning

image.altText: a rugby league team celebrates winning a grand final

props.synopsis: With the likes of Will Kennedy and Ben Barba on their side, Walgett was able to beat the equally star-studded Nanima Common Connection 46-12. On the women's side, the Redfern All Blacks avenged their 2023 grand final loss.

title.children: Walgett takes home back-to-back Koori Knockout titles with help from NRL stars

image.altText: A building sign that reads 'ACT Civil and Administrative Tribunal'.

props.synopsis: In its final ruling the ACT Civil and Administrative Tribunal found overwhelming support for the conclusion pit bull cross Buddha posed a risk to the safety of the public and other animals.

title.children: 'Threat to people and other dogs': Canberra owner fails to overturn ruling her dog should be destroyed

image.altText: Nicola Gobbo has blonde hair and stares off screen.

props.synopsis: Lawyer X Nicola Gobbo has told a civil trial she thought she'd only have to be a police informer for a few weeks. Instead, she said, her life became like a spy novel.

title.children: 'How stupid was I?': Nicola Gobbo tells court about undercover missions and secret meetings
